notesStmt.note: A satiric dialogue referring to the Treaty of Ryswick.

Reproduction of the original in: Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DIALOGUE Between the French King, And the LATE King JAMES.
A DIALOGUE Between the French King, And the LATE King JAMES, At St. Germains en Laye: Occa≈øion'd by the Signing of the PEACE.
LONDON: Printed for Richard Baldwin, near the Oxford-Arms in Warwick-Lane. 1697.

div.head: A DIALOGUE Between the French King, And the Late King JAMES.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: I hope your Maje≈øty will excu≈øe my want of Breeding. To tell you the Truth, Sir, I am quite out of love with any thing of French.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Why ≈øo out of humour, Sir?

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Not without Cau≈øe, Sir, if I may be a Judge in my own Ca≈øe; I pre≈øume your Maje≈øty cannot but know the Occa≈øion.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, not I; Madam de Maintenon and I have been Solacing our ≈øelves, congratulating each other upon the good News of a Peace.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: And I upon the ≈øame Account have been Cur≈øing my Cruel Fate, and Fal≈øe Friends.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you are not come to affront me. But that I am in an extream good Humour, I might have re≈øented ≈øuch an Expre≈ø≈øion.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Your Maje≈øty may do with me as you plea≈øe; I have lo≈øt Three Kingdoms already, and I have nothing left now worth lo≈øing.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Come, Sir, let me de≈øire you to curb your Pa≈ø≈øion, and guide your ≈øelf by Rea≈øon.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Is this a time to talk of Rea≈øon, when Experience tells me I am in a fair way to beg my Bread?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: As you promi≈øed me, Sir, and as I promi≈øed my dear Friends ≈øoon after I came here, That you would not put up your Sword, till you had revenged my Quarrel, and replaced me on the Throne from whence the Heretical Crew expelled me.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
'Tis true, Sir, I drew my Sword, and will not put it up my ≈øelf; yet upon a ≈øecond Con≈øideration, the Dauphin ≈øhall; and really it is not ju≈øt he ≈øhould inherit a wa≈øted Kingdom, nor that I ≈øhould
entail upon him a perpetual War with his Neighbours; therefore I have advi≈øed him to take your Grandfather's Motto, Beati Pacifici; knowing by my own Experience the fatal Mi≈øchiefs of War.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I think you cannot in Honour make a Peace with the Prince of Orange, ≈øo long as he keeps me out of my Throne.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Put Intere≈øt in one Scale, and Honour in the other, you'll find it a meer Trifle.‚ÄîNece≈ø≈øity has no Law.‚ÄîYou have been my Pen≈øioner the≈øe Nine Years, and not only your ≈øelf and Bedfellow, but the little Prince, as you call him, and a Gallimaufrey of Highlanders, Rapparees, and Renegado's, have been fed and cloathed at my Charge. Is all this nothing?

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Wor≈øe than nothing, Sir, except you had compleated that meritorious Work of Re-enthroning me. But if I had had the lea≈øt thoughts how I ≈øhould have been ≈øerved, I would long ere now have come to Compo≈øition with my Subjects: The Engli≈øh are naturally Hone≈øt and Good natur'd, and I am per≈øwaded would have allowed me the Intere≈øt, though not the Principal.‚ÄîBut now, Sir, I have no hopes.‚Äî

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
Recollect your Memory, and you may remember that I lent you an Army in Ireland, which with your own Courage, and the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øome able Friends in England and Scotland, might have enabled you to regain your Po≈øt; but no ≈øooner did the King of England offer you Battle, but away you run, and left my Men to
be knockt o'th' Head at the Boyne.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Natural Infirmities, Sir, you know are unavoidable. 'Twas nothing but what I deriv'd from my peaceable Grandfather; my Brother Charles had a little of his Hypocri≈øy, and I too much of his Courage; yet, Sir, I can remember how I ≈øwing'd the Dutch bravely, when I peept out of my Fortification of Cable-Ropes, and cried Halloo Boys, halloo. Oh! how I made the Rogues ≈øcamper!‚Äîbut now I grow old and unfit for Martial Exerci≈øe.‚Äî

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
Luis d'ores you have ≈øquandred away without number, under pretence of Secret Service, for ≈øupplying the Nece≈ø≈øities of the Loyal Clergy, for Corre≈øpondence with Great Men at Court; providing Arms and Ammunition to beat up the Prince of Orange's Quarters,
and a round Sum for Pamphleteers, New-writers, Ballad-makers, Private Pre≈ø≈øes, and Wagerers.‚ÄîBut where's the Fruit of all this?

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Sir, you are too ha≈øty; I had as fine a Plot on the Stocks as any Je≈øuit in Europe could invent, and would have Launcht it in two or three Months, if this damn'd Peace had not prevented it.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Well remembred; This brings to mind your fertile Inventions and Abortive Executions. I ≈øuppo≈øe you have not forgot the Chevalier Granvil's good Succe≈øs; That was a rare Contrivance of yours, o' my word, had it been well effected!

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Succe≈øs is not in the Hands of Man, Sir; if it were, I had had as good Succe≈øs with the Prince of Orange, as you had with the Duke of Loraine.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Your Son Berwick offered to bring the Prince of Orange Dead or Alive, upon Condition that I would give him a Mar≈øhals Staff; but that Project fail'd.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir; the Duke took the Sacrament on't, but forgot Ned Petres Benediction. I'm ≈øure I did my endeavour on my bare Knees; and if Ave-Mary's and Pater-No≈øter's would have effected it, I had carried the Day. For my part, I believe the Virgin was a≈øleep, and St. Loyala thick of hearing, el≈øe why ≈øhould I be thus di≈øappointed?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
I'll tell you why, Sir; your Faith has not been well-grounded; you have expected Mountains, and are fain to content your ≈øelf with Mole-hills; Could you ever think to rea≈ø≈øume your Abdicated Throne, by the help of a pack of de≈øperate
forlorn Fellows, who have liv'd upon the Odd Pence you could ≈øpare out of my Allowance? And whil≈øt they pretended a Tenderne≈øs of Con≈øcience, would have cut your own Throat with as little Remor≈øe as Rookwood or Cranbourn would have A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinated your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: I am per≈øuaded, Sir, That Glorious Work had been done by my Faithful Servants and Martyrs, had not tho≈øe Two Traitors, De La Rue, and Pendergra≈øs told Tales. I ≈øay, Sir, A man can do no more than he can do; and if ≈øuch Enterprizes fail, we are the le≈øs beholden to Heaven.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
I am ≈øorry, Sir, you are Born under ≈øo Malevolent a Planet; If my Stars had been ≈øo unkind to me, I ≈øhould ≈øcarce have been Louis Le Grand now, and weathered the
Point through ≈øo many Campaigns as I have done. But now I grow in years, it is high time to be quiet, for I'd fain go to Heaven in Peace.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: 'Tis True, you have had better ≈øucce≈øs than I, Sir; but you may thank your Ammunition, Sir, 'tis that has done you many a good piece of Service. You Charg'd your Cannon with Luid'ores, and fill'd your Bombs with Pi≈øtoles, which upon the fir≈øt Di≈øcharge made the Gates fly open, and the Governors your Humble Servants.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
Not always neither; you may remember how A≈øhby put a Trick upon me, and was the occa≈øion of my lo≈øing the Royal-Sun, and put the Chevalier de Tourville in ≈øuch a Di≈øorder, that I could never ≈øince get him to look the Engli≈øh Fleet in the Face,
though between you and I, I never intended he ≈øhould.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: That was a Di≈øappointment, Sir; But how was I ≈øerved at Salisbury! but I'll ≈øay that for my ≈øelf, if my No≈øe had not bled, I'd have ≈øpoil'd the Dutch having Trade for ever; but ≈øuch things are ominous.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: To none but Cowards, Sir; you might have kept your Kingdoms till now, had you ≈øhuffled your Cards well; but you Drove too fa≈øt to keep your ≈øelf i'th Box.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p:
I did all for the be≈øt, Sir, out of a tender regard to Mother-Church. It was upon that account, Sir, That I ≈øent my Brother Charles to Heaven a little before his Time. He was too ≈øluggi≈øh to promote the Catholick Intere≈øt, and therefore I ≈øent him
packing. In requital for this, and ≈øome other little Tricks I put upon my Subjects, they ≈øent me to take the Air at St. Germains; but I'll remember 'em, if ever I make 'em another Vi≈øit.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
None but a Madman would hope for ≈øuch a thing. However, Sir, I be≈øeech you don't rely upon me for any A≈ø≈øi≈øtance; for to tell you the truth, I have done the utmo≈øt that lay in my power; I have Exhau≈øted my Kingdom to that degree, both of Men and Money, that 'tis e'en heart ≈øick, and I am afraid I ≈øhall hardly live to ≈øee it recover again. I have flung away Million after Million to gain the Univer≈øal Monarchy, but am farther from it now than ever. Had it not been for ≈øome Tru≈øty Corre≈øpondents in England, who now and then pre≈øented me
with a Brace or two of Ea≈øt-India Men, or a Virginia Fleet, I had been quite Unhing'd long ago.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: I hope your Maje≈øty forgets the Service my Privateers have done ≈øometimes.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Now and then, Sir, they have brought me in a Collier, or a Mackeril-Boat, but that won't pay my Armies. As for my Fleet, I have made but little u≈øe of them ≈øince the Surfeit they got at La Hogue, which made 'em keep a long Quarrantain at Thoulon to my Co≈øt, I'm ≈øure, whil≈øt the Confederates very bountifully flung their Fireworks into my Sea-port Towns for joy. But if you had had no other Allowance than the Purcha≈øe of your Privateers, you might have drank Small Beer and Beverage, in≈øtead of Champain and Burgundy.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: My Men are afraid the Prince of Orange will put 'em to the ≈øqueak, if he gets 'em; and they are naturally aver≈øe to the ≈ømell of Engli≈øh Hemp. But if I live to ≈øee England again, I'll make your Maje≈øty amends.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Pray don't let the thoughts of a Kingdom di≈øturb you: I had great hopes once of being King of Great Britain my Self, and that would have made me Amends ≈øufficient: But now neither you nor I are like to be the better for it.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, to ≈øpeak like a Philo≈øopher, Crowns are but Encumbrances; yet it goes a little again≈øt the grain, to ≈øee my Son-in-Law take up my Crown, before I think fit to lay it down.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p:
You know the Engli≈øh Proverb, What can't be cur'd, mu≈øt be ‚Ä¢ ndur'd. I have told you more than
once, I have done to the utmo≈øt of my Ability; and I had better make a Peace with Honour, than be compell'd to it by Force. Heaven runs counter to all my De≈øigns, and in≈øtead of giving Peace, I ≈øhall in a little time be glad to beg it: For Money I have none, and Men grow ≈øcarce; la≈øt Year I was in great hopes to have broke the League, and then I'de have pickt the Bones of the Confederates one after another, but that fail'd. This Year I made ≈øure of the Spani≈øh Flota that would have fill'd my Bags bravely, but was fain to content my ≈øelf with the Plunder of Carthagena, and glad I got off ≈øo: The Engli≈øh Fleet have made them≈øelves amends by Sacking Petit Guaves, and Snapping the Buccaniers. So that when all the≈øe things are con≈øidered, I ≈øhall hardly be Two-pence the better for the Expedition.
I thought Pointi's Cargo would have been Gold Du≈øt and Diamonds; but in≈øtead of that, he has brought me home the Twelve Apo≈øtles and the Virgin Mary, which for fear of di≈øplea≈øing the Clergy, I dare not melt.‚ÄîYou can't be ignorant what Showers of Gold I rain'd in Poland, to get the Crown for Conti, but there the Rogues have ≈øhamm'd me, and cho≈øe the Elector of Saxony. My good Friends and Allies at the Port are put to the Rout by the Imperiali≈øts: I wi≈øh I had Cheteau-Neuf in my Cabinet at Marli, he'll be torn a-pieces for telling ≈øuch a pack of Lies. I made 'em believe I was ≈øtrong enough to rai≈øe Contributions as far as the Gates of Vienna, but in≈øtead of that, Mon≈øieur Choi≈øeul is fain to content him≈øelf with pa≈ø≈øing and repa≈ø≈øing the Rhine, and has the ≈øatisfaction of ≈øeeing Eberenbourg
taken before his Face. 'Tis true, I took Barcelona and Aeth, but had it not been to gain the Grand Point, I had rather have let it alone; however it has ≈øaved the Hangman a labour, and me the trouble of Di≈øbanding a great many, who for want of Employment have turned Free-booters. And in Flanders, do what I can, your Son-in-Law is too cunning for me.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Then your Maje≈øty is re≈øolved to ≈øign Peace.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: It is already done, Sir.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: And has your Maje≈øty acknowledged the Prince of Orange King of England whil≈øt I live?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Upon the Word of a King I have.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: I hope your Maje≈øty has ob≈øerved the Di≈øtinction between a King de Facto and de Jure.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, it is too late now to mind Di≈øtinctions; I have done it, and can't undo it if I would; I mu≈øt be a Slave to my Word now; and to confirm the Sincerity of my Intentions, have given him his Principality of Orange into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Then I'm undone indeed, for I de≈øign'd to have begg'd that for my ≈øhare, and he ≈øhould have been a Titular Prince as well as my ≈øelf. But what Provi≈øion for my Son, the Prince of Wales?

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: None at all, Sir; if you are willing to take my Advice, ≈øend him to his Mother, if you know where to find her; or if you had rather, I'll prefer him to be a Valet de Chambre to the Dutche≈øs of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p:
No, Sir, I'll make him a Clergy-man, he's a forward Child.
But, pray Sir, what ≈øeparate Article for the Relief of tho≈øe faithful, tho unfortunate Fools, the afflicted and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Cavaliers in England? I expect the fir≈øt Fleet from thence will bring over ≈øome Thou≈øands to implore your Maje≈øty's Protection. I have nothing left to Succour or Support them my ≈øelf, but I hope your mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty won't forget their Service.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: No, Sir, by no means, I de≈øign to pre≈øent them to the King of Morocco; he's a dull Fellow, yet has done me ≈øome little Service again≈øt the Spaniards, and I ought to make him amends; but if he has no occa≈øion for them, they'll ≈øerve to ≈øtock my Plantations; they have been Sick of the Scurvy a long time, cour≈øe Fare, and hard Labour will be good for the Health of their Bodies.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.p: Now it comes into my head, What does your Maje≈øty think of a De≈øcent upon Jeru≈øalem, and the Holy Land? That would be a glorious Conque≈øt.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, trouble me no more with your Projects; I'll per≈øuade the Old Gentleman to ≈øend you a Cardinal's Cap to ≈øtrengthen your Whim≈øical Brain; and for your Spou≈øe, when an Abbe≈øs≈øhip is vacant, I won't forget her. And ≈øo, Sir, adieu.

sp.speaker: K. J.
sp.l: I'll bear my Cro≈øs with Patience if I can;
Ah! Coleman, Coleman, there's no Faith in Man.
